name: Agent Gateway
summary: A Rust-based proxy that sits between agents and their targets (MCP servers, A2A agents, LLMs, APIs), adding security, auth, rate limiting, and observability. This is the protocol-level equivalent of a network firewall for agents. Crucially, Agent Gateway makes other protocols MORE visible — it's an anti-Kafka tool that adds feedback loops and audit trails where none existed. Paired with Kagent for Kubernetes-native agent orchestration.

feedbackLoop.note: Explicitly designed to ADD feedback loops: metrics, tracing, audit logs for all agent traffic.

edgeCases.note: Must support MCP, A2A, REST, and LLM inference protocols simultaneously — many edge cases in translation.

ambiguity.note: Policy enforcement is deterministic: auth passes or fails, rate limits are clear.

redundancy.note: Unique positioning — no other protocol specifically addresses agent security at the proxy layer.

nesting.note: Adds another layer to every agent interaction: agent → gateway → target. Extra hop, extra potential failure.

exitCost.note: Early stage, open source. Gateway layer is interchangeable by design.

identityPenetration.note: Pure infrastructure. No identity formation around 'gateway builders.'

agencyPreservation.note: Increases participant agency — gives operators visibility and control over agent traffic they didn't have before.

controlInvisibility.note: Makes control MORE visible, not less. This is the rare protocol that counteracts the invisibility problem.

crisisMindset.note: 'MCP has security gaps — you need a gateway NOW' — some urgency framing, but grounded in real vulnerabilities.
